title: How was Genghis Khan able to successfully avoid a succession crisis between his sons following his death? - Quora

response.answer_text: Through intense negotiation and keeping each son satisfied with land.  Genghis Khan and three of his four sons Even during Genghis Khan’s lifetime, there had been signs of tension among two of his sons: Jochi and Chagatai. Jochi felt that he had the right to become the Great Khan because he was the oldest. Chagatai refuted this on the basis that Jochi probably wasn’t Genghis Khan’s son. Jochi’s paternity had always been in doubt. During her capture by the Merkid tribe and before she gave birth to Jochi, Genghis Khan’s wife Borte may have been raped, which is why Chagatai sometimes called Jochi a “Merkid bastard.” Trying to prevent a potential civil war, Genghis Khan summoned his four sons to a kurultai in 1221. He recognized Jochi as his oldest son and wanted the others to do the same. However, Chagatai refused. He knew that he had infuriated his father to point that he would never become his heir, but he could still prevent Jochi from becoming the Great Khan. Eventually, they reached a conclusion. Ogodei, who neither brother particularly hated, would become the Great Khan. Chagatai would rule Transoxiana while Jochi’s family would rule over the section of the empire closest to Europe.* By picking a non-factitious heir and handing out appanages to his remaining sons, Genghis Khan managed to avoid a succession crisis after his death. *It’s also worth noting that Jochi predeceased his father anyway
